Properties.Description: The predicted / forecasted power output for a generator for a period of time.

NewEntity.Description: The predicted / forecasted power output for a generator for a period of time.

NewEntity.Name: Transaction

Columns.Name: TransactionId
Columns.Description: The unique identifier of a Transaction.

Columns.Name: TransactionInitiatedTimestamp
Columns.Description: The timestamp the transaction was initiated.

Columns.Name: TransactionCompletedTimestamp
Columns.Description: The timestamp that the transaction was completed or closed.

Columns.Name: TransactionReceivedTimestamp
Columns.Description: The timestamp that the Transaction was received.

Columns.Name: TransactionEntryTimestamp
Columns.Description: The timestamp that the Transaction was entered into the appropriate system for processing.

Columns.Name: TransactionConfirmationTimestamp
Columns.Description: The timestamp that the Transaction was confirmed to the Customer/Customer Account.

Columns.Name: CreditCheckTimestamp
Columns.Description: The timestamp that the Customer/Customer Account had a credit check in regard to the Transaction amount.

Columns.Name: RequestedDeliveryDate
Columns.Description: The date that the Customer/Customer Account requested delivery of the items.

Columns.Name: CommittedDeliveryDate
Columns.Description: The date committed to the Customer/Customer Account for delivery of the items.

Columns.Name: ActualDeliveryTimestamp
Columns.Description: The actual timestamp of delivery of the items to the Customer/Customer Account.

Columns.Name: DeliveryConfirmationTimestamp
Columns.Description: The timestamp that confirmation of the delivery or Shipment was made to the Customer/Customer Account.

Columns.Name: TransactionAmount
Columns.Description:
The amount associated with the transaction.

Ex:
Refund = 'amount'
Credit = 'amount'

Columns.Name: ShipmentToName
Columns.Description: The name of the ship-to party.

Columns.Name: ShipmentToLocationId
Columns.Description: The unique identifier of a Location.

Columns.Name: TransactionConfirmationNumber
Columns.Description: The transaction confirmation number provided to confirm that the transaction was executed.

Columns.Name: IdentificationCheckedIndicator
Columns.Description: Indicates whether the individual's identification was checked for any requirements for the transaction. For example: The individual is 21 years of age or older in order to purchase alcohol products.

Columns.Name: IdentificationId
Columns.Description: The unique identifier of the identification.

Columns.Name: TotalRetailPriceAmount
Columns.Description: The total list price value of the Transaction products = (list price per unit product price)x(quantity ordered) for each line item.

Columns.Name: TotalAdjustmentPercentage
Columns.Description: The total percentage of adjustment(s) applied to the Transaction.

Columns.Name: TotalAdjustmentAmount
Columns.Description: The total amount of adjustments applied to the Transaction.

Columns.Name: TotalTransactionSalesPriceAmount
Columns.Description: The total actual price value of the transaction item(s) = (actual selling price per unit product price)x(quantity) for each line item.

Columns.Name: TotalShippingChargeAmount
Columns.Description: The total amount of shipping charge associated with the Transaction.

Columns.Name: TransactionTotalTaxAmount
Columns.Description: The total amount of all taxes applied to the Transaction.

Columns.Name: TransactionRoundingAmount
Columns.Description: The amount of rounding applied to the transaction. This is typically done when the payment method is cash and the total invoice amount is rounded to an amount that is payable using legal tender. (e.g. 1 cent coin is no longer in legal circulation.)

Columns.Name: TransactionTotalInvoicedAmount
Columns.Description: The total invoiced amount to the Customer/Customer Account.

Columns.Name: TotalCommissionsPayableAmount
Columns.Description: The total amount of commissions payable and due in regard to the Transaction.

Columns.Name: SplitCommissionsIndicator
Columns.Description: Indicates that the commissions are to be split between two or more employees.

Columns.Name: RequestedShipmentCarrierName
Columns.Description: The name of the Carrier for the Shipment requested by the Customer/Customer Account.

Columns.Name: AlternateCarrierAcceptableIndicator
Columns.Description: Indicates that an alternate Carrier of the Shipment would be acceptable to the Customer/Customer Account.

Columns.Name: ShipCompleteIndicator
Columns.Description: Indicates that the Transaction item(s) are only to be shipped when complete - no partial shipments.

Columns.Name: AcknowledgementRequiredIndicator
Columns.Description: Indicates that an acknowledgement  to the Customer/Customer Account is required for the Transaction.

Columns.Name: ExpediteTransactionIndicator
Columns.Description: Indicates that the Transaction is to be expedited.

Columns.Name: DropShipmentIndicator
Columns.Description: Indicates that the Transaction item(s) are to be drop shipped.

Columns.Name: ActualShipmentCarrierName
Columns.Description: The Carrier of the Shipment.

Columns.Name: TotalWeight
Columns.Description: The total weight of the Transaction item(s).

Columns.Name: TotalFreightChargeAmount
Columns.Description: The total freight charges amount.

Columns.Name: UnitOfMeasureId
Columns.Description: The unique identifier of a Unit Of Measure.

Columns.Name: EarliestDeliveryWindowTimestamp
Columns.Description: The earliest timestamp that the transaction should be made available for delivery.

Columns.Name: LatestDeliveryWindowTimestamp
Columns.Description: The latest timestamp that the transaction should be made available for delivery.

Columns.Name: DeliveryInstructions
Columns.Description: Instructions related to the delivery of the Transaction item(s).

Columns.Name: CustomerCreditCheckNote
Columns.Description: A note, comment or additional information regarding the Transaction credit check.

Columns.Name: MessageToCustomer
Columns.Description: A message to the Customer/Customer Account regarding the Transaction.

Columns.Name: CustomerId
Columns.Description: The unique identifier of a Customer.

Columns.Name: CustomerAccountId
Columns.Description: The unique identifier of a Customer Account.

Columns.Name: PurchasingChannelId
Columns.Description: The unique identifier of a Channel.

Columns.Name: SalesChannelId
Columns.Description: The unique identifier of a Channel.

Columns.Name: DistributionChannelId
Columns.Description: The unique identifier of a Channel.

Columns.Name: MarketingEventId
Columns.Description: The unique identifier of a Marketing Event.

Columns.Name: AdvertisingEventId
Columns.Description: The unique identifier of an Advertising Event.

Columns.Name: PromotionId
Columns.Description: The unique identifier of a Promotion.

Columns.Name: PartialReturnIndicator
Columns.Description: Indicates that only a part of the original transaction was returned or refunded.

Columns.Name: TransactionTypeId
Columns.Description: The unique identifier of a Transaction Type.

Columns.Name: BillingCycleId
Columns.Description: The unique identifier of a Billing Cycle.

Columns.Name: MerchantId
Columns.Description: The unique identifier of a Merchant.

Columns.Name: CustomerIdentificationMethodId
Columns.Description: The unique identifier of a customer identification method.

Columns.Name: TransactionClassificationId
Columns.Description: The unique identifier of an Transaction Classification.

Columns.Name: TransactionProcessingStatusId
Columns.Description: The unique identifier of a Transaction Processing Status.

Columns.Name: IsoCurrencyCode
Columns.Description: The ISO 4217 currency code.

Columns.Name: TransactionExecutionMethodId
Columns.Description: The unique identifier of a Transaction Execution Type.

Columns.Name: TransactionPriorityId
Columns.Description: The unique identifier of a Transaction Priority.

Columns.Name: TransactionTaxStatusId
Columns.Description: The unique identifier of a Transaction Tax Status.

Columns.Name: WebpageUrl
Columns.Description:
The unique address of any Web document.

The URL consists of:
Type of file (ex: http://)
Domain name (ex: www. name.com)
Path or directory to file (ex: /notes/internet)
Name of file (...name.html)

Columns.Name: SessionId
Columns.Description: The unique identifier of a Session.

Columns.Name: WorkstationSessionId
Columns.Description: The unique identifier of a Workstation Session.

Columns.Name: PointOfSaleId
Columns.Description: The unique identifier of a POS.

Columns.Name: StoreId
Columns.Description: The unique identifier of a Store.

Columns.Name: WarehouseId
Columns.Description: The unique identifier of a Warehouse.

Columns.Name: ResponsibilityCenterId
Columns.Description: The unique identifier of a Responsibility Center.

Columns.Name: TransactionNote
Columns.Description: A note, comment or additional information regarding the Transaction.

Columns.Name: ShipmentMethodId
Columns.Description: The unique identifier of a Shipment Method.

Columns.Name: DeviceId
Columns.Description: The unique identifier of a Device.

Columns.Name: SoftwareProductId
Columns.Description: The unique identifier of a software product.

Columns.Name: SoftwareProductVersionNumber
Columns.Description: The version number of the software product.

Columns.Name: ApprovedByEmployeeId
Columns.Description: The unique identifier of an Employee.

Columns.Name: PromotionOfferId
Columns.Description: The unique identifier of a Promotion Offer. The Promotion Offer ID is unique to each account or party that is offered to.

Columns.Name: LoyaltyCardId
Columns.Description: The unique identifier of a Loyalty Card.

Columns.Name: ProductId
Columns.Description: The unique identifier of a Product.

Columns.Name: ProductName
Columns.Description: The name of the Product, which normally corresponds to the 'marketing name' of the Product.

Columns.Name: ProductDescription
Columns.Description: The description of the Product.

Columns.Name: IntroductionDate
Columns.Description: The date that the Product was introduced for sale.

Columns.Name: PlannedAbandonmentDate
Columns.Description:
The planned date to discontinue marketing the product.    

Abandonment is a component in the decline stage of the product's life cycle characterized by a reduced market demand for the product and an increased number of competing products with similar characteristics.

There are three (3) strategies for abandoning a product:

(1)  Reduced marketing and expenditures to maintain profits.

(2)  Concentrating on the strongest market segments and eliminating the weaker market segments

(3)  Maintain the marketing level until the product is discontinued.

Columns.Name: ActualAbandonmentDate
Columns.Description:
The actual date that the marketing of the product was discontinued. 

Abandonment is a component in the decline stage of the product's life cycle characterized by a reduced market demand for the product and an increased number of competing products with similar characteristics.

There are three (3) strategies for abandoning a product:

(1)  Reduced marketing and expenditures to maintain profits.

(2)  Concentrating on the strongest market segments and eliminating the weaker market segments

(3)  Maintain the marketing level until the product is discontinued.

Columns.Name: PrimaryBrandId
Columns.Description: The unique identifier of a Brand.

Columns.Name: Trademark
Columns.Description: A 'trademark' is a brand name or brand mark that is given legal protection.

Columns.Name: ProductLogo
Columns.Description: A design, symbol or series of words that identifies the product.

Columns.Name: UniversalProductCode
Columns.Description:
A system that identifies products by type and by manufacturer.  

A UPC consists of eleven (11) digits.  Six (6) indicate the Manufacturer and five (5) digits describe the product.

UPCs appear on product packages as bar codes, which are graphic symbols that are read by optical scanner devices.   

UPCs are assigned by the Uniform Code Council of Dayton, Ohio.

Columns.Name: InformationLabelText
Columns.Description: The label text that identifies the care, use, preparation and handling or the product.

Columns.Name: DescriptiveLabelText
Columns.Description: The label text that describes significant characteristics and benefits.

Columns.Name: WarningInformationText
Columns.Description: The text of the warning label, if any, appearing upon the product.

Columns.Name: GovernmentWarningLabelText
Columns.Description: The US Government (or foreign government) label text that addressing the US legal requirements of the Product.

Columns.Name: FederallyFundedServiceIndicator
Columns.Description: Indicates that funding was federally-provided.

Columns.Name: StateFundedServiceIndicator
Columns.Description: Indicates that funding was state-provided.

Columns.Name: LocallyFundedServiceIndicator
Columns.Description: Indicates that funding was locally-provided.

Columns.Name: LowIncomeEligibleProductIndicator
Columns.Description: A product eligible for low-income customers.

Columns.Name: GreenProductIndicator
Columns.Description: Indicates that the product is a 'green' or environmentally-friendly product.

Columns.Name: ItemSku
Columns.Description: The Stock Keeping Unit identifier, which is typically used for inventory-related activities.

Columns.Name: ProductTypeId
Columns.Description: The unique identifier of a Product Type.

Columns.Name: WarrantyId
Columns.Description: The unique identifier of a Warranty.

Properties.Description:
A product is anything that can be offered to a market that might satisfy a want or need by potential customers.    That product is the sum of all physical, psychological, symbolic, and service attributes associated with it.

There are two basic types of products:

- Tangible (physical)
- Intangible (non-physical) such as services

A service is a non-material or intangible product - such as professional consultancy, maintenance service, repair service etc.
Each product has its own benefits, application, brand name, and packaging that gives it its own identity and distinguishing characteristics.

Every business or organization has business rules that define precisely what a product is.    While we intuitively know what a product is, we must quantify that knowledge and associated business rules with consistent definitions that can be implemented within the organization in strategies and applications.

A product typically goes through five stages of development:

(1) Idea Stage - involving a thorough evaluation of the potential product

(2) Concept Stage - determines customer acceptance by testing and presentation to consumers and distribution channel members.   Specific aspects regarding quality, dependability, reliability, warranty, packaging, service, pricing, terms of sale, sales and distribution channels, advertising and promotions are evaluated.

(3) Product Development Stage - transforms the prototype product into an actual product for mass sale.   This stage requires close interaction between both marketing and manufacturing.

(4) Test Marketing Stage - may or may not be used since it is an expensive and time-consuming process.  Test marketing involves evaluating various product options and alternatives.

(5) Commercialization - It is very expensive to launch a new product so commercialization only applies to those specific products that are actually going to be sold to the market.

Products tend to be categorized as either:  Industrial goods and consumer goods

Industrial goods are used to produce other products .

Industrial goods may be further divided into:

- Raw materials
- Equipment
- Pre-built materials 
- Supplies.

Consumer goods are intended for consumption by the general public.

Consumer goods may be further divided into:

- Durable goods
- Nondurable goods
- Packaged goods

A product may be a member of a product family or product line.

A product family is a grouping of products or services that are related to each other by common function, functionality, design platform or similar characteristics.

Members of a product family frequently have many common parts and assemblies.

Product families are the highest level of grouping for forecasting, capacity planning or related functions.

Ex:
The Apple Macintosh family of products consists of the product lines:
- Mac mini
- MacBook Pro
- Mac Pro

A product line is a grouping of products that are closely related in usage, functionality or marketing characteristics.

A Product Family typically is created to address one or five functions:

1. To increase profits and not erode the sales of existing products

2. To attract additional Markets or Market Segments

3. To counter competitor's products

4. To fill a gap in an existing Product Family.

5. To promote sales of other products in the family line

Line Depth refers to the number of products in the product line.

Line consistency refers to how closely related the products are that make up the product line.

Line vulnerability refers to the percentage of sales or profits that are derived from only a few products in the product line.

Product width refers to the number of different product lines sold by a company.

Product mix refers to the total number of products sold in all product lines.

Line extension refers to the adding of a new product to a line.

"Trading up or brand leveraging" refers to adding a product of better quality to a product line than the other products in that line.

"Trading down" refers to adding a product of lesser quality to a product line than the other products in that line.

If a line of products is sold with the same brand name, this is referred to as family branding.
Strategy and decisions regarding a product line are usually incorporated in a high-level marketing plan addressing product line strategy, sales, channels, distribution channels, pricing and related issues.
A product-line manager is responsible for a product line and supervises several product managers who are responsible for individual products within the line.
Product-line managers typically have the following responsibilities:
- Expansion and composition of a product line
- Evaluate the effects of product mixes on the profitability of other items in the line
- Planning and allocation of resources to individual products in the line
A product is normally associated with a brand strategy - manufacturer, private or generic.

1. Manufacturer-  or 'national' branding in which the brand is assigned by the manufacturer of the Product.

2. Private - or 'dealer' branding in which the brand is assigned by the retailer or wholesaler of the Product.

3. Generic - in which the Product is not marked with any identification.   Generic brands are a means for manufacturers to increase profits by saving on advertising, packaging or other costs associated with manufacturer or private branding.

A brand is name, term, sign, symbol or design or a combination of these which identify the goods or services and differentiate them from those of competitors'

A Trade mark is a brand or some part of the brand that is given legal protection because it is capable of exclusive appropriation and representation.

Manufacturers can use their own brands (known as Manufacturers' brands) or brands of their distributors (Distributors' brands).

Manufacturers/ distributors use brand names for a variety of reasons ranging from simple identification purposes to having legal protection for unique features of the products from imitations.

Brands help consumers recognize certain quality parameters. In some cases, brands are just used to endow the product with unique story and character which itself can be a basis for product differentiation.

Individual brands have their own identity and the corporate or common name is not used to promote its equity.

Individual branding requires more expensive advertising and brand extensive brand creation investments.  By extension, each new brand does not benefit from the positive perceptions of earlier brands.

By contrast, family branding has several advantages.

Each new product is quickly associated with the other products and brand in terms of quality and benefits.

Reduced or eliminated time for name identification and advertising for name recognition purposes.

NewEntity.Name: Vendor

Columns.Name: VendorId
Columns.Description: The unique identifier of a Vendor.

Columns.Name: VendorName
Columns.Description: The business name of the Vendor.

Columns.Name: VendorNote
Columns.Description: A narrative, description or additional detail regarding the associated Vendor.

Columns.Name: VendorTypeId
Columns.Description: The unique identifier of a Vendor Type.

Columns.Name: VendorDateOfEstablishment
Columns.Description: The date that the Vendor was established.

Columns.Name: StateOfVendorEstablishment
Columns.Description: The state in which the Vendor was established.

Columns.Name: CountryOfVendorEstablishment
Columns.Description: The country in which the Vendor was established.

Columns.Name: StateOfVendorResidence
Columns.Description: The state in which the Vendor has it's primary business or official residence.

Columns.Name: CountryOfVendorResidence
Columns.Description: The country in which the Vendor has it's primary business or official residence.

Columns.Name: FirstDateOfOperation
Columns.Description: The first date that the Vendor entered into normal business or operations.

Columns.Name: CurrentManagementFirstControlDate
Columns.Description: The date that current management assumed control of the Vendor's normal business operations.

Columns.Name: StockExchangeName
Columns.Description: The name of the stock exchange that the security is listed upon.

Columns.Name: ListedSecuritySymbol
Columns.Description: The security symbol of the Vendor, if any.

Columns.Name: BankruptcyIndicator
Columns.Description: Indicates that bankruptcy proceeding exist for the Vendor customer, which is a proceeding under the U.S. Bankruptcy Code, in which either a debtor files a bankruptcy petition and voluntarily seeks protection from creditors, or creditors file a bankruptcy petition against a debtor to force the debtor to pay debts owed to them.

Columns.Name: SmallBusinessIndicator
Columns.Description: Indicates that business is a small business by SBA guidelines.

Columns.Name: ManufacturingIndicator
Columns.Description: Notes manufacturing operations occur at site.

Columns.Name: ForeignOwnedIndicator
Columns.Description: Identifies companies with parent outside of the U.S.

Columns.Name: DunsNumber
Columns.Description: The DUNS number is a nine-digit number issued by Dun & Bradstreet and assigned to each business location in the D&B database having a unique, separate, and distinct operation to businesses for the purpose of identifying them. The number as issued is random and the digits apparently have no significance as to their issuance.

Columns.Name: DunBradstreetSingleLocationSubsidiary
Columns.Description:
There are eight (8) types of business relationships defined in D&B WorldBase:

Single Location Subsidiary

A single location subsidiary has reporting responsibilities to its parent; however, it does not have branches or subsidiaries reporting to it. Do not confuse this with a stand-alone business which is titled "single location" and is not part of a corporate family.

Headquarters

A headquarters is a business establishment that has branches or divisions reporting to it, and is financially responsible for those branches or divisions. If the headquarters is more that 50% owned by another corporation, it also will be a subsidiary. If it owns more that 50% of another corporation, then it is also a parent.

Branch

A branch is a secondary location of its headquarters. It has no legal responsibility for its debts, even though bills may be paid from the branch location. It will have the same legal business name as its headquarters, although branches frequently operate under a different trade style than the headquarters establishment. A branch may be located at the same address as the headquarters if it has a unique trade style. In such cases, the branch may appear to be a duplicate with a different D-U-N-S number than the headquarters record, which may confuse customers if they don't purchase the trade style field.

Division

Subsidiary

A subsidiary is a corporation that is more than 50% owned by another corporation and will have a different legal business name from its parent company. A subsidiary may have branches and/or subsidiaries of its own. If it does, then its D-U-N-S Number appears in the headquarter/parent D-U-N-S Number field of its children.

Parent

A parent is a corporation that owns more than 50 percent of another corporation. The parent company also may be a subsidiary of another corporation. If the parent also has branches, then it is also a headquarters.

Domestic Ultimate

Single Location Subsidiary

A single location subsidiary has reporting responsibilities to its parent; however, it does not have branches or subsidiaries reporting to it. Do not confuse this with a stand-alone business which is titled "single location" and is not part of a corporate family.

Headquarters

A headquarters is a business establishment that has branches or divisions reporting to it, and is financially responsible for those branches or divisions. If the headquarters is more that 50% owned by another corporation, it also will be a subsidiary. If it owns more that 50% of another corporation, then it is also a parent.

Branch

A branch is a secondary location of its headquarters. It has no legal responsibility for its debts, even though bills may be paid from the branch location. It will have the same legal business name as its headquarters, although branches frequently operate under a different trade style than the headquarters establishment. A branch may be located at the same address as the headquarters if it has a unique trade style. In such cases, the branch may appear to be a duplicate with a different D-U-N-S number than the headquarters record, which may confuse customers if they don't purchase the trade style field.

Division

A division, like a branch, is a secondary location of a business. However, a division carries out specific business operations related to the headquarters under a divisional name. Divisions look similar to branches in D&B WorldBase and carry a branch code.

Subsidiary

A subsidiary is a corporation that is more than 50% owned by another corporation and will have a different legal business name from its parent company. A subsidiary may have branches and/or subsidiaries of its own. If it does, then its D-U-N-S Number appears in the headquarter/parent D-U-N-S Number field of its children.

Parent

NewEntity.Name: Warehouse

Columns.Name: WarehouseId
Columns.Description: The unique identifier of a Warehouse.

Columns.Name: WarehouseName
Columns.Description: The name of the Warehouse.

Columns.Name: LocationId
Columns.Description: The unique identifier of a Location.

Columns.Name: GlobalLocationNumber
Columns.Description: The Global Location Number (GLN) is a simple tool used to uniquely identify locations. It can be used to identify physical locations such as a warehouse, legal entities, or a function / department within a legal entity. The GLN is part of the GS1 system of standards.

Columns.Name: WarehouseTelephoneNumber
Columns.Description: The Warehouse Telephone Number.

Columns.Name: WarehouseFaxNumber
Columns.Description: The Warehouse Fax Number.

Columns.Name: WarehouseEmailAddress
Columns.Description: The Warehouse email address.

Columns.Name: PickAndPackLeadTime
Columns.Description: The default time required to pick and pack an item at a warehouse.

Columns.Name: WarehouseOrderCutoffTime
Columns.Description: The latest time each day that new orders will be accepted for delivery for the next scheduled delivery day.

Columns.Name: TotalFloorSpace
Columns.Description: The total floor space at the Warehouse.

Columns.Name: TotalFloorInventoryStorageSpace
Columns.Description: The total floor space at the Warehouse that is available for storage of inventory.

Columns.Name: StorageSpaceUnitOfMeasureId
Columns.Description:
The unit of measure for the size measurement of the Warehouse.

Ex:
- square feet
- square meter

Columns.Name: ContractWarehouseIndicator
Columns.Description:
A contract warehouse is a business that handles shipping, receiving, and storage of products on a contract basis.  

Contract warehouses will generally require a client to commit to a specific period of time (generally in years) for the services.  

Contracts may or may not require clients to purchase or subsidize storage and material-handling equipment.  

Fees for contract warehouses may be transaction and storage based, fixed, cost plus, or any combination.

Columns.Name: StoreId
Columns.Description: The unique identifier of a Store.

Columns.Name: CustomerId
Columns.Description: The unique identifier of a Customer.

Columns.Name: CustomerOwnedWarehouseIndicator
Columns.Description: Indicates whether the customer owns the warehouse.

Columns.Name: CustomerManagedWarehouseIndicator
Columns.Description: Indicates whether the customer manages the warehouse.

Columns.Name: InventoryOwnedByCustomerIndicator
Columns.Description: Indicates whether the inventory stored at the warehouse inventory location is owned by the customer.

Columns.Name: WarehouseTypeId
Columns.Description: The unique identifier of a warehouse type.

NewEntity.Name: AdvertisingEvent
NewEntity.Description:
A specific, discreet execution, performance or placement of a single Advertising Collateral.

An Advertising Campaign may coordinate and affect more than one Advertising Collaterals via multiple Advertising Events.

Columns.Name: AdvertisingEventId
Columns.Description: The unique identifier of an Advertising Event.

Columns.Name: AdvertisingEventDescription
Columns.Description: The description of the Advertising Event.

Columns.Name: ExecutionStartTimestamp
Columns.Description: The start timestamp for the execution of the associated Advertising Event.

Columns.Name: ExecutionEndTimestamp
Columns.Description: The end timestamp for the execution of the associated Advertising Event.

Columns.Name: AdvertisingEventLocation
Columns.Description: The location of the Advertising Event.

Columns.Name: AdvertisingEventContactWebpage
Columns.Description: The webpage that the advertising event refers viewers to.

Columns.Name: AdvertisingEventContactTelephoneNumber
Columns.Description: The telephone number that the advertising event refers viewers to.

Columns.Name: PreemptedReplayStartTimestamp
Columns.Description: The timestamp of the start of the replay of the advertising event.

Columns.Name: PreemptedReplayEndTimestamp
Columns.Description: The timestamp of the end of the replay of the advertising event.

Columns.Name: LocalAdvertisingIndicator
Columns.Description: Commercials marketed to a local sales area and placed by local or regional advertisers.

Columns.Name: NationalAdvertisingIndicator
Columns.Description: Indicates that the advertising event is national in scope.

Columns.Name: AdvertisingEventPreemptedIndicator
Columns.Description: Indicates that the Advertising Event was preempted.

Columns.Name: AdjacencyAdvertisingEventIndicator
Columns.Description: Commercials strategically placed next to a feature.

Columns.Name: AdvertisingCampaignId
Columns.Description: The unique identifier of an Advertising Campaign.

Columns.Name: AdvertisingCategoryId
Columns.Description: The unique identifier of an Advertising Category.

Columns.Name: DeliveryChannelId
Columns.Description: The unique identifier of a Delivery Channel.

Columns.Name: AgencyId
Columns.Description: The unique identifier of an Agency.

Columns.Name: ProductId
Columns.Description: The unique identifier of a Product.

Columns.Name: AdvertisingEventTypeId
Columns.Description: The unique identifier of an advertising event type.

Columns.Name: BrandId
Columns.Description: The unique identifier of a Brand.

NewEntity.Name: BillingCycle
NewEntity.Description:
The period upon which the Customer or Customer Account is regularly billed or statements issued.

Examples:
- Bi-Weekly
- Weekly

Properties.Description:
The period upon which the Customer or Customer Account is regularly billed or statements issued.

Examples:
- Bi-Weekly
- Weekly
- Monthly
- Quarterly
- Annually
- Per Transaction
- One-time
- At time of event

NewEntity.Name: Carrier
NewEntity.Description:
A company or corporation engaged in transporting passengers or goods (mail, freight or cargo)

Any entity who, in a contract of carriage, undertakes to perform or to procure the performance of carriage by rail, road, sea, air, inland waterway or by a combination of such modes.

Ex:
-  United Airlines
-  Air Canada
-  Aer Lingus
-  UPS
-  Federal Express
-  US Postal Service
-  DHL
-  American President Lines
-  Maersk- Sealand

Carriers are often identified by their 2 or 3 character abbreviation. Ex.:

CARRIER NAME                           2-Char Abbr.   3-Char. Abbr.  4-dig Census Code
~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~

AIR CANADA                             AC             ACA            5100
AIR NEW ZEALAND, LIMITED               NZ             ANZ            5005
BRITISH AIRWAYS P.L.C.                 BA             BAW            2250
DELTA AIRLINES (DELTA CONNECTIO        DL             DAL            0128

Columns.Name: CarrierId
Columns.Description: The unique identifier of a Carrier.

Columns.Name: CarrierName
Columns.Description: The name of a Carrier.

Columns.Name: CarrierTypeId
Columns.Description: The unique identifier of a Carrier Type.

Columns.Name: CarrierOfficeTelephoneNumber
Columns.Description: The Carrier's telephone number.

Columns.Name: CarrierOfficeFaxNumber
Columns.Description: The Carrier's fax number.

Columns.Name: CarrierOfficeEmailAddress
Columns.Description: The Carrier's email address.

Columns.Name: ScacCommonCarrierCode
Columns.Description: Standard Carrier Abbreviation Code identifying an individual common carrier. A three letter carrier code followed by a suffix identifies the carrier's equipment. A suffix of "U" is a container and "C" is a chassis.

Columns.Name: CarrierTwoCharacterCode
Columns.Description: The two character code that is used to identify the carrier.

Columns.Name: CarrierThreeCharacterCode
Columns.Description: The three character code that is used to identify the carrier.

Columns.Name: IataAirlineDesignator
IcaoAirlineDesignator
Columns.Description:
The ICAO airline designator is a code assigned by the International Civil Aviation Organization (ICAO) to aircraft operating agencies, aeronautical authorities, and services related to international aviation, each of whom is allocated both a three-letter designator and a telephony designator. These codes are unique by airline, unlike the IATA airline designator codes (see section above). The designators are listed in ICAO Document 8585: Designators for Aircraft Operating Agencies, Aeronautical Authorities and Services.

An example is:

Operator: American Airlines
Three-letter designator: AAL (the original ICAO-two-letter-designator AA was used until 1987 and is also the IATA code of the airline)
Telephony designator: AMERICAN

Columns.Name: CarrierWebsiteUrl
Columns.Description: The URL (website address) of the Carrier.

Columns.Name: FirstOperationDate
Columns.Description: The date that the Carrier was first in operation.

Columns.Name: VendorId
Columns.Description: The unique identifier of a Vendor.

Columns.Name: PartyId
Columns.Description: The unique identifier of a Party.

Columns.Name: RegionalAirlineIndicator
Columns.Description: Regional airlines are airlines that operate regional aircraft to provide passenger air service to communities without sufficient demand to attract mainline service.

Columns.Name: LowCostCarrierIndicator
Columns.Description: A low-cost carrier or low-cost airline (also known as a no-frills, discount or budget carrier or airline) is an airline that offers generally low fares in exchange for eliminating many traditional passenger services.

Columns.Name: CharterAirlineIndicator
Columns.Description: Air charter is the business of renting an entire aircraft.

Columns.Name: CargoAirlineIndicator
Columns.Description: An airline that carries cargo.

Columns.Name: NationalAirlineIndicator
Columns.Description: Many countries have national airlines that the government owns and operates.

Columns.Name: InternationalAirlineIndicator
Columns.Description: An airline that operates international routes.

Columns.Name: CarrierLogo
Columns.Description: The carrier's logo.

Columns.Name: CombinationCarrierIndicator
Columns.Description: Scheduled air carriers who transport both passengers and cargo in passenger configured aircraft, with cargo restricted to the lower deck compartments.

Columns.Name: DirectAirCarrierIndicator
Columns.Description: An air carrier that operates airplanes on a scheduled or contract (charter) basis, or both, and provides transportation for a charge.  An airline as opposed to a freight forwarder.

Columns.Name: BondedCarrierIndicator
Columns.Description: A firm that has posted bond with the government and is licensed to carry and hold in their facilities' goods that have not been granted a clearance by countries' Customs Authorities.

Columns.Name: BondedDate
Columns.Description: The date that the carrier was bonded.

Columns.Name: IataCarrierIndicator
Columns.Description: An airline which is a member of IATA and may accept, carry, and bill for air shipments. Intra-US counterpart is ATA.

Columns.Name: UnapprovedIndirectAirCarrierIndicator
Columns.Description: An indirect air carrier who has not completed the FAA security training program and does not have an FAA identification number.

Columns.Name: IntegratedCarrierIndicator
Columns.Description: A carrier that provides door-to-door air cargo transportation using its own or contracted airplanes and motor trucks, and performs this service under the authority of a singe air waybill (e.g. United Parcel Service and Federal Express).

Columns.Name: FaaIdentificationNumber
Columns.Description: A unique identifier given to an air carrier by the FAA once they have successfully completed a security training program.

Columns.Name: CommonCarrierIndicator
Columns.Description: A transportation company which provides service to the general public at published rates.

Columns.Name: DunsNumber
Columns.Description: The DUNS number is a nine-digit number issued by Dun & Bradstreet and assigned to each business location in the D&B database having a unique, separate, and distinct operation to businesses for the purpose of identifying them. The number as issued is random and the digits apparently have no significance as to their issuance.

Columns.Name: DunBradstreetSingleLocationSubsidiary
Columns.Description:
There are eight (8) types of business relationships defined in D&B WorldBase:

Single Location Subsidiary

A single location subsidiary has reporting responsibilities to its parent; however, it does not have branches or subsidiaries reporting to it. Do not confuse this with a stand-alone business which is titled "single location" and is not part of a corporate family.

Headquarters

A headquarters is a business establishment that has branches or divisions reporting to it, and is financially responsible for those branches or divisions. If the headquarters is more that 50% owned by another corporation, it also will be a subsidiary. If it owns more that 50% of another corporation, then it is also a parent.

Branch

A branch is a secondary location of its headquarters. It has no legal responsibility for its debts, even though bills may be paid from the branch location. It will have the same legal business name as its headquarters, although branches frequently operate under a different trade style than the headquarters establishment. A branch may be located at the same address as the headquarters if it has a unique trade style. In such cases, the branch may appear to be a duplicate with a different D-U-N-S number than the headquarters record, which may confuse customers if they don't purchase the trade style field.

Division

A division, like a branch, is a secondary location of a business. However, a division carries out specific business operations related to the headquarters under a divisional name. Divisions look similar to branches in D&B WorldBase and carry a branch code.

Subsidiary

A subsidiary is a corporation that is more than 50% owned by another corporation and will have a different legal business name from its parent company. A subsidiary may have branches and/or subsidiaries of its own. If it does, then its D-U-N-S Number appears in the headquarter/parent D-U-N-S Number field of its children.

Parent

A parent is a corporation that owns more than 50 percent of another corporation. The parent company also may be a subsidiary of another corporation. If the parent also has branches, then it is also a headquarters.

Domestic Ultimate

The Domestic Ultimate is a subsidiary within the global family tree which is the highest ranking member within a specific country.

Global Ultimate

The Global Ultimate is the top most responsible entity within the global family tree. The Global Ultimate may have branches and/or subsidiaries reporting directly or indirectly to it.

Single Location Subsidiary

A single location subsidiary has reporting responsibilities to its parent; however, it does not have branches or subsidiaries reporting to it. Do not confuse this with a stand-alone business which is titled "single location" and is not part of a corporate family.

Headquarters

A headquarters is a business establishment that has branches or divisions reporting to it, and is financially responsible for those branches or divisions. If the headquarters is more that 50% owned by another corporation, it also will be a subsidiary. If it owns more that 50% of another corporation, then it is also a parent.

Branch

A branch is a secondary location of its headquarters. It has no legal responsibility for its debts, even though bills may be paid from the branch location. It will have the same legal business name as its headquarters, although branches frequently operate under a different trade style than the headquarters establishment. A branch may be located at the same address as the headquarters if it has a unique trade style. In such cases, the branch may appear to be a duplicate with a different D-U-N-S number than the headquarters record, which may confuse customers if they don't purchase the trade style field.

Division

A division, like a branch, is a secondary location of a business. However, a division carries out specific business operations related to the headquarters under a divisional name. Divisions look similar to branches in D&B WorldBase and carry a branch code.

Subsidiary

A subsidiary is a corporation that is more than 50% owned by another corporation and will have a different legal business name from its parent company. A subsidiary may have branches and/or subsidiaries of its own. If it does, then its D-U-N-S Number appears in the headquarter/parent D-U-N-S Number field of its children.

Parent

A parent is a corporation that owns more than 50 percent of another corporation. The parent company also may be a subsidiary of another corporation. If the parent also has branches, then it is also a headquarters.

Domestic Ultimate

The Domestic Ultimate is a subsidiary within the global family tree which is the highest ranking member within a specific country.

Global Ultimate

The Global Ultimate is the top most responsible entity within the global family tree. Properties.Description:
A company or corporation engaged in transporting passengers or goods (mail, freight or cargo)

Any entity who, in a contract of carriage, undertakes to perform or to procure the performance of carriage by rail, road, sea, air, inland waterway or by a combination of such modes.

Ex:
-  United Airlines
-  Air Canada
-  Aer Lingus
-  UPS
-  Federal Express
-  US Postal Service
-  DHL
-  American President Lines
-  Maersk- Sealand

Carriers are often identified by their 2 or 3 character abbreviation. Ex.:

CARRIER NAME                           2-Char Abbr.   3-Char. Abbr.  4-dig Census Code
~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~

AIR CANADA                             AC             ACA            5100
AIR NEW ZEALAND, LIMITED               NZ             ANZ            5005
BRITISH AIRWAYS P.L.C.                 BA             BAW            2250
DELTA AIRLINES (DELTA CONNECTIO        DL             DAL            0128

NewEntity.Name: Channel
NewEntity.Description: A channel is a means by which products or services are sold and/or distributed.

Columns.Name: ChannelId
Columns.Description: The unique identifier of a Channel.

Columns.Name: ChannelName
Columns.Description: The name of the associated Channel.

Columns.Name: ChannelCode
Columns.Description: An arbitrary code assigned to or associated with a Channel. This code does not necessarily have to be unique.

Columns.Name: LocationId
Columns.Description: The unique identifier of a Location.

Columns.Name: ChannelLogo
Columns.Description: A design, symbol or series of words that identifies the channel.

Columns.Name: TelephoneNumber
Columns.Description: The channel telephone number.

Columns.Name: FaxNumber
Columns.Description: The channel fax number.

Columns.Name: EmailAddress
Columns.Description: The channel email address.

Columns.Name: ChannelCommencementDate
Columns.Description: The date that the channel commenced operations.

Columns.Name: ChannelCloseDate
Columns.Description: The date that the channel was permanently closed.

Columns.Name: ChannelCategoryId
Columns.Description: The unique identifier of a Channel Category.

Columns.Name: ChannelTypeId
Columns.Description: The unique identifier of a Channel Type.

Columns.Name: PartyId
Columns.Description: The unique identifier of a Party.

Columns.Name: DunsNumber
Columns.Description: The DUNS number is a nine-digit number issued by Dun & Bradstreet and assigned to each business location in the D&B database having a unique, separate, and distinct operation to businesses for the purpose of identifying them. The number as issued is random and the digits apparently have no significance as to their issuance.

Columns.Name: DunBradstreetSingleLocationSubsidiary
Columns.Description:
There are eight (8) types of business relationships defined in D&B WorldBase:

Single Location Subsidiary

A single location subsidiary has reporting responsibilities to its parent; however, it does not have branches or subsidiaries reporting to it. Do not confuse this with a stand-alone business which is titled "single location" and is not part of a corporate family.

Headquarters

A headquarters is a business establishment that has branches or divisions reporting to it, and is financially responsible for those branches or divisions. If the headquarters is more that 50% owned by another corporation, it also will be a subsidiary. If it owns more that 50% of another corporation, then it is also a parent.

Branch

A branch is a secondary location of its headquarters. It has no legal responsibility for its debts, even though bills may be paid from the branch location. It will have the same legal business name as its headquarters, although branches frequently operate under a different trade style than the headquarters establishment. A branch may be located at the same address as the headquarters if it has a unique trade style. In such cases, the branch may appear to be a duplicate with a different D-U-N-S number than the headquarters record, which may confuse customers if they don't purchase the trade style field.

Division

A division, like a branch, is a secondary location of a business. However, a division carries out specific business operations related to the headquarters under a divisional name. Divisions look similar to branches in D&B WorldBase and carry a branch code.

Subsidiary

A subsidiary is a corporation that is more than 50% owned by another corporation and will have a different legal business name from its parent company. A subsidiary may have branches and/or subsidiaries of its own. If it does, then its D-U-N-S Number appears in the headquarter/parent D-U-N-S Number field of its children.

Parent

A parent is a corporation that owns more than 50 percent of another corporation. The parent company also may be a subsidiary of another corporation. If the parent also has branches, then it is also a headquarters.

Domestic Ultimate

The Domestic Ultimate is a subsidiary within the global family tree which is the highest ranking member within a specific country.

Global Ultimate

The Global Ultimate is the top most responsible entity within the global family tree. The Global Ultimate may have branches and/or subsidiaries reporting directly or indirectly to it.

A branch may be located at the same address as the headquarters if it has a unique trade style. In such cases, the branch may appear to be a duplicate with a different D-U-N-S number than the headquarters record, which may confuse customers if they don't purchase the trade style field.

Division

A division, like a branch, is a secondary location of a business. However, a division carries out specific business operations related to the headquarters under a divisional name. Divisions look similar to branches in D&B WorldBase and carry a branch code.

Subsidiary

A subsidiary is a corporation that is more than 50% owned by another corporation and will have a different legal business name from its parent company. A subsidiary may have branches and/or subsidiaries of its own. If it does, then its D-U-N-S Number appears in the headquarter/parent D-U-N-S Number field of its children.

Parent

A parent is a corporation that owns more than 50 percent of another corporation. The parent company also may be a subsidiary of another corporation. If the parent also has branches, then it is also a headquarters.

Domestic Ultimate

The Domestic Ultimate is a subsidiary within the global family tree which is the highest ranking member within a specific country.

Global Ultimate

The Global Ultimate is the top most responsible entity within the global family tree. The Global Ultimate may have branches and/or subsidiaries reporting directly or indirectly to it.

A branch may be located at the same address as the headquarters if it has a unique trade style. In such cases, the branch may appear to be a duplicate with a different D-U-N-S number than the headquarters record, which may confuse customers if they don't purchase the trade style field.

Division

A division, like a branch, is a secondary location of a business. However, a division carries out specific business operations related to the headquarters under a divisional name. Divisions look similar to branches in D&B WorldBase and carry a branch code.

Subsidiary

A subsidiary is a corporation that is more than 50% owned by another corporation and will have a different legal business name from its parent company. A subsidiary may have branches and/or subsidiaries of its own. If it does, then its D-U-N-S Number appears in the headquarter/parent D-U-N-S Number field of its children.

Parent

A parent is a corporation that owns more than 50 percent of another corporation. The parent company also may be a subsidiary of another corporation. If the parent also has branches, then it is also a headquarters.

Domestic Ultimate

The Domestic Ultimate is a subsidiary within the global family tree which is the highest ranking member within a specific country.

Global Ultimate

The Global Ultimate is the top most responsible entity within the global family tree. The Global Ultimate may have branches and/or subsidiaries reporting directly or indirectly to it.","isNullable":true,"name":"DunBradstreetUltimate"},{"type":"Existing","attributeReference":{"entity":"Channel.cdm.json/Channel","name":"DunBradstreetGlobalUltimate"},"dataType":"boolean","description":"There are eight (8) types of business relationships defined in D&B WorldBase:

Single Location Subsidiary

A single location subsidiary has reporting responsibilities to its parent; however, it does not have branches or subsidiaries reporting to it. Do not confuse this with a stand-alone business which is titled "single location" and is not part of a corporate family.

Headquarters

A headquarters is a business establishment that has branches or divisions reporting to it, and is financially responsible for those branches or divisions. If the headquarters is more that 50% owned by another corporation, it also will be a subsidiary. If it owns more that 50% of another corporation, then it is also a parent.

Branch

A branch is a secondary location of its headquarters. It has no legal responsibility for its debts, even though bills may be paid from the branch location. It will have the same legal business name as its headquarters, although branches frequently operate under a different trade style than the headquarters establishment. A branch may be located at the same address as the headquarters if it has a unique trade style. In such cases, the branch may appear to be a duplicate with a different D-U-N-S number than the headquarters record, which may confuse customers if they don't purchase the trade style field.

Division

A division, like a branch, is a secondary location of a business. However, a division carries out specific business operations related to the headquarters under a divisional name. Divisions look similar to branches in D&B WorldBase and carry a branch code.

Subsidiary

A subsidiary is a corporation that is more than 50% owned by another corporation and will have a different legal business name from its parent company. NewEntity.Name: Contract
NewEntity.Description: A written agreement between two or more parties specifying the terms and conditions under which business obligations will be performed.

Columns.Name: ContractId
Columns.Description: The unique identifier of a Contract.

Columns.Name: ContractDescription
Columns.Description: The description of the contract.

Columns.Name: ContractLegalReviewDate
Columns.Description: The date that the legal review of the associated Contract was completed.

Columns.Name: ContractSignedDate
Columns.Description: The date that the Contract was signed.

Columns.Name: ContractEffectiveStartDate
Columns.Description: The date that the Contract goes into effect.

Columns.Name: ContractEffectiveEndDate
Columns.Description: The date that the Contract is terminated or expires.

Columns.Name: ContractPeriodMonths
Columns.Description: The number of months that the contract is to be in effect.

Columns.Name: AutomaticRenewalIndicator
Columns.Description: Indicates that the Contract is to be automatically renewed upon expiration.

Columns.Name: AutomaticRenewalNotificationPeriod
Columns.Description: The period in days in which the Contract holder is to be notified in advance that the Contract is due to expire.

Columns.Name: PrepaidContractIndicator
Columns.Description: Indicates that the Contract is prepaid by the Contract holder.

Columns.Name: ContractUrl
Columns.Description: Website address for contract related reference.

Columns.Name: ContractVersion
Columns.Description:
An edition identifier used for business purposes to label business significant variants.

The identifier that is used to identify this version of the contract when it is referenced in a specification, model, design, instance, or contract derivative. This is an arbitrary value managed by the contract author and is not expected to be globally unique. For example, it might be a timestamp (e.g. yyyymmdd) if a managed version is not available. There is also no expectation that versions can be placed in a lexicographical sequence.

Columns.Name: PrimaryJurisdictionId
Columns.Description: The unique identifier of a Jurisdiction.

Columns.Name: MultipleJurisdictionIndicator
Columns.Description: Indicates whether more than one jurisdiction has authority to exercise their powers over the contract.

Columns.Name: GoverningRuleOfLawJurisdictionId
Columns.Description: The unique identifier of a Jurisdiction.

Columns.Name: MultipleGoverningRuleOfLawJurisdictionIndicator
Columns.Description: Indicates whether more than one jurisdiction governs the rule of law over the contract.

Columns.Name: BankruptcyCondition
Columns.Description: A description of the terms and conditions under which bankruptcy will affect or void the associated Contract or terms therein.

Columns.Name: RevocationOfOfferBySellerCondition
Columns.Description: A description of the condition(s) under which the Seller may revoke a tendered offer to provide or sell items under the associated Contract.

Columns.Name: TermsOfOfferConditions
Columns.Description: A description of the item offering terms provided by the Seller under the associated Contract.

Columns.Name: RelapseOfReasonableTimeCondition
Columns.Description: A description of the condition(s) under which the purchaser may void the terms of the contract due to the seller being unable to provide the items covered by the Contract.

Columns.Name: RejectionOfOfferByBuyerCondition
Columns.Description: A description of the conditions under which the buyer may reject items provided under offer by the Seller in connection with the associated  Contract.

Columns.Name: ContractTypeId
Columns.Description: The unique identifier of a Contract Type.

Columns.Name: ContractCategoryId
Columns.Description: The unique identifier of a contract category.

Columns.Name: IsoCurrencyCode
Columns.Description: The ISO 4217 currency code.

Columns.Name: IsoLanguageId
Columns.Description: The unique identifier of an ISO Language.

Columns.Name: CustomerAccountId
Columns.Description: The unique identifier of a Customer Account.

NewEntity.Name: Currency
NewEntity.Description:
The definition of Currency is based upon the ISO 4217 standard.

ISO 4217 is the international standard describing three letter codes (also known as the currency code) to define the names of currencies established by the International Organization for Standardization (ISO). 

The first two letters of the code are the two letters of ISO 3166-1 alpha-2 country codes (which are similar to those used for national top-level domains on the Internet) and the third is usually the initial of the currency itself. So Japan's currency code becomes JPY-JP for Japan and Y for yen. This eliminates the problem caused by the names dollar, franc and pound being used in dozens of different countries, each having significantly differing values. Also, if a currency is revalued, the currency code's last letter is changed to distinguish it from the old currency. In some cases, the third letter is the initial for "new" in that country's language, to distinguish it from an older currency that was revalued; the code often long outlasts the usage of the term "new" itself. Examples of this include the Mexican peso (MXN) and the Turkish lira (TRY). Other changes can be seen, however; the Russian ruble, for example, changed from RUR to RUB, where the B comes from the third letter in the word "ruble".

There is also a three-digit code number assigned to each currency, in the same manner as there is also a three-digit code number assigned to each country as part of ISO 3166. This numeric code is usually the same as the ISO 3166 numeric code. For example, USD (US Dollar) has code 840 which is also the numeric code for US (United States).

The standard also defines the relationship between the major currency unit and any minor currency unit. Often, the minor currency unit has a value that is 1/100 of the major unit, but 1/10 or 1/1000 are also common. Some currencies do not have any minor currency unit at all. In others, the major currency unit has so little value that the minor unit is no longer generally used (e.g. the Japanese sen, 1/100th of a yen). Mauritania does not use a decimal division of units, setting 1 ouguiya (UM) = 5 khoums, and Madagascar has 1 ariary = 5 iraimbilanja. This is indicated in the standard by the currency exponent. For example USD has exponent 2, while JPY has exponent 0.

ISO 4217 includes codes not only for currencies, but also for precious metals (gold, silver, palladium and platinum; by definition expressed per one troy ounce, as compared to "1 USD") and certain other entities used in international finance, e.g. Special Drawing Rights. There are also special codes allocated for testing purposes (XTS), and to indicate no currency transactions (XXX). These codes all begin with the letter "X". The precious metals use "X" plus the metal's chemical symbol; silver, for example, is XAG. ISO 3166 never assigns country codes beginning with "X" while these codes are assigned for privately customized use only (reserved, never for official codes), so ISO 4217 can use "X" codes for non-country-specific currencies without risk of clashing with future country codes.

This is a list of global currencies and the three-character currency codes that we have found are generally used to represent them. 

In most cases, the currency code is composed of the country's two-character Internet country code plus an extra character to denote the currency unit.

For example, the code for Canadian Dollars is simply Canada's two-character Internet code ("CA") plus a one-character currency designator ("D").

ISO 4217 (Codes for the Representation of Currencies and Funds) defines three-letter abbreviations for world currencies. 

The general principle used to construct these abbreviations is to take the two-letter abbreviations defined in ISO 3166 (Codes for the Representation of Names of Countries) and append the first letter of the currency name (e.g., USD for the United States 

In the case of currencies defined by supra-national entities, ISO 4217 assigns two-letter entity codes starting with "X" to use in place of country codes (e.g., XCD for the Central Caribbean Dollar). 

The following are examples:

USD  America (United States of America), Dollars
AUD  Australia, Dollars
CAD  Canada, Dollars

Columns.Name: IsoCurrencyCode
Columns.Description: The ISO 4217 currency code.

Columns.Name: CurrencyName
Columns.Description: The name of the currency.

Columns.Name: CountryId
Columns.Description: The unique identifier of the Country.

Columns.Name: CurrencySymbol
Columns.Description: The symbol associated with the currency.

NewEntity.Name: CustomerAccount
NewEntity.Description:
An 'account' is an administrative means of defining one or more relationships between the customer and the selling or service-providing organization.

The Customer/ Account relationship reflects the way in customers interact with business in the real world - so that systems which are developed reflect real-world business practices and are consistent with the way business is performed.

A customer may have one or more accounts with a business. This is more likely the case with a legal entity but may also be true for individuals.   

For example, a large corporation may have many accounts with a business. Each account may be assigned to a specific department or function.

This account structure reflects the way business is done in the real world and provides a 'drill-down' capability from ultimate customer to each of the accounts. It also provides a means of consolidating customer account information to the ultimate customer level.

Columns.Name: CustomerAccountId
Columns.Description: The unique identifier of a Customer Account.

Columns.Name: CustomerAccountName
Columns.Description: The name of the Customer Account.

Columns.Name: CustomerAccountOpenedDate
Columns.Description:
The date that the customer account was opened.

Note:
This date may be the same as the churn-from date if there is a churn-from relationship identified.

Columns.Name: CustomerAccountClosedDate
Columns.Description:
The date that the customer account was closed.

Note:
This date may be the same as the churn-to date if there is a churn-to relationship identified.

Columns.Name: GlobalServiceRelationshipNumber
Columns.Description: The Global Service Relationship Number (GSRN) is part of the GS1 system of standards. It is used to identify the relationship between a service provider and a service recipient.

Columns.Name: CustomerId
Columns.Description: The unique identifier of a Customer.

Columns.Name: ResponsibilityCenterId
Columns.Description: The unique identifier of a Responsibility Center.

Columns.Name: SubaccountOfCustomerAccountId
Columns.Description: The unique identifier of a Customer Account.

Columns.Name: LedgerId
Columns.Description: The unique identifier of a Ledger.

Columns.Name: LedgerAccountNumber
Columns.Description: The unique identifier of a Ledger Account.

Columns.Name: IsoCurrencyCode
Columns.Description: The ISO 4217 currency code.

Columns.Name: CustomerAccountTypeId
Columns.Description: The unique identifier of a Customer Account Type.

Columns.Name: CustomerAccountApplicationNumber
Columns.Description: The application number associated with the creation of the Customer Account.

NewEntity.Name: CustomerIdentificationMethod
NewEntity.Description:
The method by which customers are identified.   Customers in many industries are anonymous unless they are the paying customer and pay by credit card, coupon etc.

Ex:
- Account Holder
- Credit Card
- Loyalty Card
- Promotion
- Coupon
- Anonymous Customer
- Known Customer

NewEntity.Name: EmployeeOrderCredit
NewEntity.Description:
Credit that are assigned or awarded to Employees in conjunction with the associated Order but are not commissions.    

Credits may be for assisting in a certain volume of sales or in regard to marketing programs, specific product sales, sales to specific customers etc.

Columns.Name: EmployeeId
Columns.Description: The unique identifier of an Employee.

Columns.Name: CreditDate
Columns.Description: The assignment or crediting date of the Credits.

Columns.Name: OrderId
Columns.Description: The unique number that identifies an Order.

Columns.Name: RevenueNonRevenueCreditIndicator
Columns.Description:
Indicates whether the Credits are revenue or non-revenue based.

Revenue credits are based on the invoice line items.   Non-Revenue credits are based on other things such as participating in a sale, program etc.

Columns.Name: NumberOfCreditsAwarded
Columns.Description: The number of Credits awarded or assigned to the Employee.

Columns.Name: AmountOfCreditsAwarded
Columns.Description: The amount of Credits awarded or assigned to the Employee.

Columns.Name: EmployeeOrderCreditNote
Columns.Description: A note, comment or additional information regarding the Credits.

Columns.Name: IsoCurrencyCode
Columns.Description:
The ISO 4217 currency code.

Ex:
Currency Code = AED
Currency Name = Dirham
Country Name = United Arab Emirates

Properties.Description: A document presented to customers for products delivered or services performed.

NewEntity.Name: Location
NewEntity.Description:
A location is a physical point that can be defined as a single latitude / longitude. A location can be used to describe:

- the address of a physical structure
- the location of a business or service
- the location of a component
- the delivery location for a shipment or mail

Columns.Name: LocationId
Columns.Description: The unique identifier of a Location.

Columns.Name: LocationName
Columns.Description: The name of a location.

Columns.Name: LocationDescription
Columns.Description: The description of a location.

Columns.Name: LocationAddressLine1
Columns.Description: The 'street' component of a location. Includes street name, apartment, suite number or PO Box.

Columns.Name: LocationAddressLine2
Columns.Description: The 'street' component of a location. Includes street name, apartment, suite number or PO Box.

Columns.Name: LocationCity
Columns.Description: The 'city' component of a location.

Columns.Name: LocationStateId
Columns.Description:
The unique identifier of the State = State Code.

A two-digit FIPS code assigned by the NIST to identify each State and statistically equivalent entity. The NIST assigns the codes based on the alphabetic sequence of State names (Puerto Rico and the Outlying Areas appear at the end); it documents these codes in a FIPS publication (FIPS PUB 5). Also, a two-digit code assigned by the Census Bureau to identify each State within its census geographic division (Puerto Rico and the Outlying Areas appear at the end).

Columns.Name: LocationZipCode
Columns.Description: The unique identifier of a Zip Code.

Columns.Name: LocationNote
Columns.Description: Notes, comments or additional information about the location. The note could be used to describe access to the location as well as any hazardous conditions that might exist at the location.

Columns.Name: LocationLatitude
Columns.Description:
The location north or south in reference to the equator, which is designated at zero (0) degrees. Parallel lines that circle the globe both north and south of the equator. 

Latitude is often measured in degrees, minutes, seconds (ddd mm ss), but other formats are also commonly used: gps coordinate (ddd mm.mmmm), decimal degrees (ddd.dddd).

Columns.Name: LocationLongitude
Columns.Description:
The location east or west in reference to the Prime Meridian, which is designated as zero (0) degrees longitude. The distance between lines of longitude are greater at the equator and smaller at the higher latitudes, intersecting at the earth's North and South Poles. Time zones are correlated to longitude.

Longitude is often measured in degrees, minutes, seconds (ddd mm ss), but other formats are also commonly used: gps coordinate (ddd mm.mmmm), decimal degrees (ddd.dddd).

Columns.Name: LocationDatum
Columns.Description:
Latitude and longitude are based on a datum.  A datum is a reference point, surface or axis against which measurements are made.

Different datums can be used for determining the latitude and longitude. If different datums are used the latitude and longitude for a single point (location) may be different.

WGS 84 is a datum that is used on most GPS equipment.

Columns.Name: LocationElevation
Columns.Description: The distance above sea level of this location at ground level.

Columns.Name: LocationElevationUnitOfMeasureId
Columns.Description: The elevation unit of measurement.

Columns.Name: GlobalLocationNumber
Columns.Description: The Global Location Number (GLN) is a simple tool used to uniquely identify locations. It can be used to identify physical locations such as a warehouse, legal entities, or a function / department within a legal entity. The GLN is part of the GS1 system of standards.

Columns.Name: TimezoneId
Columns.Description: The unique identifier of a timezone.

Columns.Name: DaylightSavingsTimeObservedIndicator
Columns.Description: Indicates whether daylight savings time (DST) is observed at this location.

Columns.Name: CountryId
Columns.Description: The unique identifier of the Country.

Columns.Name: SubdivisionId
Columns.Description: The unique identifier of the Country Subdivision.

NewEntity.Name: MarketingEvent
NewEntity.Description: A specific marketing event to support the objectives and goals of the associated Marketing Campaign.

Columns.Name: MarketingEventId
Columns.Description: The unique identifier of a Marketing Event.

Columns.Name: MarketingEventName
Columns.Description: The name of the Marketing Event.

Columns.Name: MarketingEventDescription
Columns.Description: The description of the Marketing Event.

Columns.Name: MarketingEventObjectivesStatement
Columns.Description:
Goals to be accomplished by an organization's overall Marketing Event such as sales, market
 share, or profitability.

Columns.Name: MarketingEventEligibilityStatement
Columns.Description: A statement regarding the eligibility requirements of the Marketing Event.

Columns.Name: MarketingEventRestrictionsStatement
Columns.Description: A statement regarding the restriction requirements of the Marketing Event.

Columns.Name: MarketingCampaignId
Columns.Description: The unique identifier of a Marketing Campaign.

Columns.Name: MarketingEventPlannedStartDate
Columns.Description:
The planned start date of the Marketing Event.
 .

Columns.Name: MarketingEventActualStartDate
Columns.Description:
The actual start date of the Marketing Event.

Note:
Planned and actual start and end dates enable management to determine whether marketing campaigns and marketing events are being planned and executed in a realistic and effective manner.

Columns.Name: MarketingEventPlannedEndDate
Columns.Description: The planned end date of the Marketing Event.

Columns.Name: MarketingEventActualEndDate
Columns.Description:
The actual end date of the Marketing Event.

Note:
Planned and actual start and end dates enable management to determine whether marketing campaigns and marketing events are being planned and executed in a realistic and effective manner.

Columns.Name: PlannedTotalNumberOfFullTimeEmployeesToBeUtilized
Columns.Description: The planned total number of full-time employees to be utilized in association with the associated Marketing Event.

Columns.Name: ActualTotalNumberOfFullTimeEmployeesUtilized
Columns.Description: The actual total number of full-time employees utilized in association with the associated Marketing Event.

Columns.Name: PlannedTotalNumberOfPartTimeEmployeesToBeUtilized
Columns.Description: The planned total number of part-time employees to be utilized in association with the associated Marketing Event.

Columns.Name: ActualTotalNumberOfPartTimeEmployeesUtilized
Columns.Description: The actual total number of part-time employees utilized in association with the associated Marketing Event.

Columns.Name: PlannedTotalNumberManDaysToBeExpended
Columns.Description: The planned total number of man-days to be expended in association with the associated Marketing Event.

Columns.Name: ActualTotalNumberManDaysExpended
Columns.Description: The actual total number of man-days expended in association with the associated Marketing Event.

Columns.Name: PlannedTotalMarketingEventCostAmount
Columns.Description: The planned total marketing campaign costs to be expended in conjunction with the Marketing Event.

Columns.Name: ActualTotalMarketingEventCostAmount
Columns.Description: The actual total marketing campaign costs expended in conjunction with the Marketing Event.

Columns.Name: MarketingEventNote
Columns.Description: A note, comment or additional information regarding a Marketing Event.

Columns.Name: MarketingEventTypeId
Columns.Description: The unique identifier of a Marketing Event Type.

Columns.Name: MarketingEventCategoryId
Columns.Description: The unique identifier of a Marketing Event Category.

Columns.Name: AdvertisingEventId
Columns.Description: The unique identifier of an Advertising Event.

Columns.Name: ProductId
Columns.Description: The unique identifier of a Product.

Columns.Name: BrandId
Columns.Description: The unique identifier of a Brand.
